Authors:
Chuan Ma, Pengcheng Yang, Feng Jiang, Marie-Pierre Chapuis,
Yasen Shali, Gregory A. Sword, Le Kang
Title:
Mitochondrial Genomes Reveal Global Phylogeography and
Dispersal Routes of the Migratory Locust
Keywords:
Locusta migratoria, migration, genetic structure,
molecular evolution, genetic divergence
Abstract:
The migratory locust, Locusta migratoria, is the most
widely distributed acridid grasshopper species in the world, but its
global genetic structure and phylogeographic relationships have not been
investigated. Here, we explored the worldwide genetic structure and
phylogeography of the locust populations based on the sequence
information from 65 complete mitochondrial genomes and 3 mitochondrial
genes of 263 individuals from 53 sampling sites. Although this locust
species can migrate over long distances, our results revealed high
genetic differentiation among these geographic populations. The
populations can be divided into two different lineages: the Northern
lineage, including individuals from the temperate regions of the
Eurasian continent; and the Southern lineage, including individuals from
Africa, southern Europe, Arabian region, India, southern China,
Southeast Asia, and Australia. Analysis of population genetic diversity
indicates that the locust species originated in Africa, and ancestral
populations likely separated into Northern and Southern lineages 861,000
years ago by vicariance events associated with Pleistocene glaciations.
These two lineages evolved in allopatry and occupied their current
distributions in the world via distinct southern and northern dispersal
routes. Genetic differences, caused by long-term independent
diversification of the two lineages, along with other factors such as
geographic barriers and temperature limitation, may play an important
role in maintaining the present phylogeographic pattern. Demographic
analysis indicates that early agricultural development promoted sudden
population expansion of the locusts in eastern China regions. Our
phylogeographic evidences challenge the long-held view of multiple
subspecies (up to eleven) in the migratory locust and tentatively divide
it into three subspecies, L. m. migratoria L., L. m. migratorioides
Reiche & Fairmaire, and L. m. capito (Saussure).
